Description: The crown jewel of Afghan cuisine featuring basmati rice cooked with lamb, caramelized carrots, raisins and aromatic spices like cardamom and cumin.
Albania's national comfort food - baked lamb and rice casserole with a velvety yogurt-egg sauce flavored with garlic and oregano.
Steamed semolina grains traditionally served with vegetables, chickpeas and slow-cooked meat in a flavorful broth, central to Algerian hospitality.
Andorra's hearty winter stew with pork, chicken, meatballs and giant pasta shells, often served in two courses (broth first, then meats).
Flavorful chicken stew made with red palm oil, garlic, okra and chili peppers, traditionally served with funge (cassava porridge).
National dish pairing cornmeal-and-okra dumplings (fungi) with a rich stew of salted meat, vegetables and fiery Antiguan peppers.
Argentina's famous barbecue featuring various cuts of beef, chorizo and morcilla sausages, slow-cooked over wood or charcoal fires.
Armenian-style barbecue where marinated pork, lamb or chicken is grilled on skewers over open flames, often served with lavash bread.
Iconic handheld pie filled with minced beef and gravy, often topped with tomato sauce ('ketchup'), considered Australia's national fast food.
Crispy breaded veal cutlet pounded thin, fried to golden perfection, traditionally served with lemon wedges and potato salad.
Azerbaijani rice pilaf featuring saffron-infused rice layered with dried fruits, chestnuts and meat, cooked in a special copper pot called kazan.
Fresh raw conch marinated in lime juice with tomatoes, onions and peppers - a refreshing Bahamian ceviche-style dish.
Bahrain's spiced rice dish with meat (usually chicken or lamb), flavored with loomi (dried lime) and baharat spice blend.
Celebrated Bengali dish featuring the prized hilsa fish cooked in mustard gravy with turmeric and chili - the taste of monsoon season.
National dish pairing cornmeal-and-okra cou-cou with pan-fried flying fish in a tomato-based sauce, reflecting Barbados' maritime heritage.
Crispy Belarusian potato pancakes made from grated potatoes and onions, traditionally served with sour cream or mushroom sauce.
Classic Belgian pairing of steamed mussels in white wine broth with crispy twice-fried potatoes, served in dedicated mussel pots.
Belize's daily staple featuring red beans and rice cooked in coconut milk, typically served with stewed chicken and potato salad.
Crunchy West African snack made from ground peanuts pressed into shapes and deep-fried, often served as a protein-rich accompaniment to meals.
Bhutan's famous chili and cheese stew where green or red chilies are cooked in a sauce of local yak cheese, butter and tomatoes.
Bolivian baked empanadas with a sweetish dough filled with juicy meat, potatoes, peas and olives, distinguished by their tear-drop shape.
Small grilled minced meat sausages made from beef and lamb, served in somun (flatbread) with raw onions and kajmak (creamy dairy spread).
Traditional Botswana pounded meat dish where beef or goat is boiled with salt until tender, then shredded and served with pap (maize porridge).
Brazil's famous black bean stew with pork cuts like ribs, sausage and smoked meat, traditionally served on Wednesdays and Saturdays with rice, collards and orange slices.
Brunei's sticky sago starch porridge eaten by twirling around bamboo sticks, dipped into flavorful sauces like cacah (spicy fruit sauce).
Flaky Bulgarian pastry made by layering filo dough with whisked eggs and sirene (white brine cheese), often eaten for breakfast with yogurt.
West African 'fat rice' cooked with tomatoes, onions and meat (usually chicken or mutton) in a rich, oily sauce that gives the dish its name.
Staple stiff porridge made from cassava or maize flour, served with beans, vegetables or meat stews, eaten throughout East Africa.
Cape Verde's slow-cooked corn and bean stew with fish or meat, considered the country's national dish with many regional variations.
Cambodia's elegant steamed fish curry wrapped in banana leaves, featuring a delicate blend of lemongrass, kaffir lime and coconut milk.
Cameroon's national dish of bitterleaf greens stewed with peanuts, shrimp and meat (usually beef or fish), served with plantains or rice.
Quebec's famous comfort food of crispy fries topped with cheese curds and smothered in rich brown gravy, now popular nationwide.
Protein-rich meatballs made from ground beef or game meat, simmered in a flavorful tomato and peanut sauce, typically served with cassava.
Staple millet or sorghum porridge that forms the base of most Chadian meals, served with sauces made from okra, meat or fish.
Chilean corn pie with a sweet corn crust layered with ground beef, chicken, olives and hard-boiled eggs - a comforting baked dish.
Beijing's iconic dish featuring crispy, lacquered duck skin served with thin pancakes, hoisin sauce and scallions - a ceremonial centerpiece.
Colombia's 'platter of the peasant' - a hearty meal with beans, rice, ground meat, chicharrón, fried egg, plantain and avocado.
Comorian lobster dish cooked with vanilla pods, garlic and spices - showcasing the islands' prized vanilla and seafood.
Signature Congolese dish of chicken stewed in palm nut sauce (moambe) with onions, garlic and chili, served with fufu or rice.
Costa Rican breakfast staple of rice and black beans stir-fried with onions, peppers and cilantro, served with eggs and sour cream.
Dalmatian beef stew marinated in wine and vinegar, slow-cooked with prunes and spices, traditionally served with gnocchi.
Cuba's national dish of shredded beef stewed with tomatoes, peppers and onions, whose name means 'old clothes' for its colorful appearance.
Cypriot barbecue featuring large chunks of marinated pork or lamb slow-roasted on a long skewer over charcoal.
Marinated beef sirloin in creamy vegetable sauce, served with bread dumplings, cranberries and whipped cream - a Czech Sunday classic.
Open-faced rye bread sandwiches artfully topped with ingredients like pickled herring, roast beef or shrimp - Denmark's edible canvas.
Spiced rice dish cooked with meat (usually goat or lamb), onions and tomatoes, influenced by Yemeni and Somali culinary traditions.
Dominica's national dish featuring legs of the giant ditch frog (called mountain chicken) stewed with garlic, lime and local spices.
The 'Dominican flag' meal of rice, red beans, meat (often chicken or beef), salad and fried plantains - the country's daily staple.
Ecuadorian version featuring shrimp or fish marinated in lime juice with tomato, onion and cilantro, often served with popcorn or plantain chips.
Egypt's beloved street food mixing rice, lentils, pasta and chickpeas, topped with crispy onions and spicy tomato sauce.
Thick corn tortillas stuffed with cheese, beans or meat, served with curtido (pickled cabbage) - El Salvador's national treasure.
Adaptation of the American dish featuring lima beans, corn and sometimes meat, reflecting the country's Afro-Spanish influences.
Spicy Eritrean beef stew simmered with berbere spice mix, tomatoes and onions, traditionally served with injera (sourdough flatbread).
Estonian blood sausage made with barley and pork blood, traditionally served during Christmas with mulgikapsad (sauerkraut stew).
Thick porridge made from ground corn, served with meat or vegetable stews - the staple carbohydrate in Swazi cuisine.
Ethiopia's famous spicy chicken stew made with berbere spice blend, hard-boiled eggs and niter kibbeh (spiced clarified butter).
Fijian ceviche where fresh fish is marinated in lime juice and coconut milk with onions, chili and tomatoes - often served in coconut shells.
Traditional Finnish pastries with thin rye crusts filled with rice porridge or mashed potatoes, often topped with egg butter.
Classic French dish of chicken braised in red wine with mushrooms, onions and bacon - a celebration of rustic French cooking.
Gabonese chicken dish cooked in palm nut sauce (nyembwe) with onions, garlic and chili - the country's most celebrated culinary specialty.
Gambian peanut stew with meat (usually beef), vegetables and tomato paste, served over rice - the country's comfort food.
Georgia's famous cheese-filled bread, with regional varieties like Adjarian khachapuri featuring an egg yolk in the center.
German pot roast marinated for days in vinegar and spices, slow-cooked until tender and served with potato dumplings and red cabbage.
Staple dough made by pounding boiled cassava and plantains, served with soups like light soup (tomato-based) or groundnut soup.
Layered casserole of eggplant, spiced ground meat and béchamel sauce - Greece's most famous baked dish with Ottoman roots.
Grenada's national one-pot meal of breadfruit, callaloo leaves, coconut milk and salted meat, cooked until the liquid is 'oiled down'.
Ancient Mayan stew blending roasted spices, seeds and chilies with meat (chicken, beef or pork), considered Guatemala's national dish.
Marinated grilled chicken with onions, mustard and lemon juice - Guinea's most famous dish with roots in the Casamance region.
West African one-pot rice dish cooked with tomatoes, onions and spices, often featuring seafood in this coastal version.
Guyanese Amerindian-derived stew of meat (usually beef) cooked with cassareep (cassava extract), cinnamon and hot peppers - a Christmas tradition.
Haitian fried pork chunks marinated in citrus and Scotch bonnet peppers, served with pikliz (spicy pickled vegetables) - the national comfort food.
Honduran flour tortilla folded with refried beans, cheese and cream - the country's most popular street food, often enhanced with eggs or meat.
Hungary's famous paprika-spiced beef stew with vegetables, originally a herdsman's dish cooked over open fires on the Puszta.
Fermented Greenland shark with a strong ammonia-rich flavor, traditionally buried for months then air-dried - Iceland's notorious delicacy.
Fragrant rice dish layered with spiced meat (chicken, mutton or fish), saffron and fried onions - the crown jewel of Mughlai cuisine.
Indonesia's famous fried rice cooked with sweet soy sauce, shallots, garlic and chili, often topped with fried egg and prawn crackers.
Iran's national dish pairing saffron-steamed basmati rice (chelow) with grilled meat kababs, often served with grilled tomatoes and sumac.
Ancient Mesopotamian dish of butterflied carp grilled over open flames and seasoned with tamarind and olive oil - Baghdad's signature dish.
Hearty lamb stew with potatoes, onions and carrots, originally a poor man's dish that became Ireland's culinary emblem.
Crispy fried chickpea balls seasoned with herbs and spices, served in pita with tahini and salads - Israel's most popular street food.
The iconic Neapolitan pizza featuring a thin crust topped with San Marzano tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella, basil leaves, and olive oil - representing the colors of the Italian flag.
Fermented cassava couscous with a light, fluffy texture, served with grilled fish and spicy onion-tomato sauce - a staple in Ivorian cuisine.
Jamaica's national dish combining sautéed salted cod with ackee (a buttery tropical fruit), onions, peppers and spices - often served with fried dumplings.
Vinegared rice combined with fresh seafood (like tuna or salmon) and vegetables, artfully presented as nigiri (hand-pressed) or maki (rolled in seaweed).
Jordan's national dish of lamb cooked in fermented dried yogurt (jameed), served over rice on flatbread - a ceremonial Bedouin dish.
Kazakh 'five fingers' dish of boiled horse or lamb meat served over flat noodles with onion sauce - traditionally eaten with hands.
Kenyan barbecue featuring grilled goat meat seasoned simply with salt, traditionally served with ugali (cornmeal) and kachumbari (tomato-onion salad).
Traditional dish of taro leaves baked with coconut cream, often wrapped in banana leaves - a staple across Pacific island nations.
Pyongyang's famous cold buckwheat noodles in icy beef broth, served with sliced pears and mustard - a North Korean summer specialty.
Spicy fermented vegetables (usually napa cabbage) seasoned with chili, garlic and ginger - the iconic Korean side dish with hundreds of varieties.
Kosovar layered pancake made by alternating thin crepe-like layers with cream or yogurt - traditionally cooked over an open fire.
Kuwaiti spiced rice dish with meat (usually chicken or lamb), flavored with loomi (dried lime) and baharat spice blend.
Kyrgyz 'five fingers' dish of boiled horse or lamb meat served over flat noodles with onion sauce - traditionally eaten with hands.
Laotian minced meat salad flavored with fish sauce, lime juice, ground toasted rice and fresh herbs - considered the country's national dish.
Traditional Latvian dish of gray peas with fried onions and speck (bacon), often served during winter solstice celebrations.
Lebanon's national dish of bulgur wheat mixed with ground meat (usually lamb) and spices, served raw, baked or fried in various forms.
Stiff maize porridge that forms the base of most Basotho meals, served with meat or vegetable stews - similar to South African pap.
Liberian version of the West African staple featuring rice cooked in tomato sauce with onions, peppers and often seafood or meat.
Libyan unleavened bread made from barley flour, traditionally served with stews like marqa (meat and vegetable stew).
Liechtenstein's version of cheese spaetzle - small dumplings mixed with melted cheese and topped with crispy onions.
Lithuanian 'zeppelins' - large potato dumplings stuffed with meat or curd, named for their airship-like shape.
Luxembourg's national dish of smoked pork collar served with broad beans in cream sauce and boiled potatoes.
Madagascar's national stew of beef with leafy greens (brèdes), tomatoes and ginger - often considered the country's signature dish.
Malawian staple of thick maize porridge, served with relishes like ndiwo (vegetable stew) or chambo (local fish).
Malaysia's national dish of coconut milk rice served with sambal, fried anchovies, peanuts and boiled egg - often called the country's unofficial national dish.
Traditional Maldivian breakfast of shredded smoked tuna mixed with coconut, onion and chili, served with flatbread (roshi).
Malian peanut butter sauce served over rice or millet, often made with chicken or beef - similar to West African groundnut stew.
Maltese rabbit stew cooked in wine with garlic and herbs - considered the national dish and centerpiece of traditional feasts.
Traditional fermented breadfruit paste, often wrapped in banana leaves and baked - a staple carbohydrate source in Marshallese cuisine.
Mauritanian version of Senegal's national dish - fish and rice cooked with vegetables in a tomato-based sauce.
Mauritian flatbread stuffed with ground split peas, served with curry - the island's most popular street food with Indian influences.
Complex sauce containing chocolate, chili peppers and spices, traditionally served over turkey or chicken for special occasions like Day of the Dead.
Traditional fermented breadfruit dish, wrapped in banana leaves and left to ferment for weeks - a staple across Micronesian islands.
Moldovan cornmeal porridge similar to polenta, traditionally served with sour cream, cheese and sometimes meat stews.
Monégasque fried pastry stuffed with Swiss chard, ricotta and sometimes meat - the principality's most famous culinary specialty.
Mongolian steamed dumplings filled with minced mutton or beef and onions - a staple food especially during Lunar New Year celebrations.
Montenegrin cornmeal porridge mixed with potatoes and kajmak (creamy dairy product), often served with cured meats or fresh cheese.
Slow-cooked stew named after the conical clay pot it's cooked in, featuring meat, fruit and spices like saffron and cinnamon.
Spicy grilled chicken marinated in piri piri chili sauce - a dish that originated in Mozambique before becoming famous worldwide.
Myanmar's national dish of rice noodles in fish broth flavored with lemongrass, banana stem and chickpea flour - considered the country's breakfast staple.
Namibian street food of grilled beef cubes, often served with chili sauce and eaten as a quick snack or light meal.
Nauruan dish of fresh reef fish cooked in coconut milk with local spices - reflecting the island's limited agricultural resources.
Nepal's staple meal of lentil soup (dal) served with steamed rice (bhat) and vegetable curries - eaten twice daily by many Nepalis.
Dutch comfort food of mashed potatoes mixed with vegetables like kale or sauerkraut, served with smoked sausage - a winter staple.
Traditional Māori method of cooking food using heated rocks buried in a pit oven, giving meats and vegetables a distinctive earthy flavor.
Nicaraguan version of rice and beans cooked together with onions and sweet peppers, typically served at breakfast with eggs and cheese.
Nigerien dish of millet or sorghum couscous served with vegetables and sometimes meat - a staple across the Sahel region.
Nigerian version of the West African staple featuring rice cooked in tomato sauce with onions, peppers and often chicken or fish.
North Macedonia's national dish of baked beans in an earthenware pot, seasoned with peppers and mint - often called 'the fasting dish'.
Norway's national dish of lamb and cabbage stew seasoned with whole black peppercorns - traditionally eaten in autumn.
Omani celebratory dish of spiced meat (usually lamb) wrapped in banana leaves and slow-cooked in an underground sand oven for up to 48 hours.
Pakistani version of the fragrant rice dish layered with spiced meat (usually chicken or mutton), saffron and fried onions.
Palauan delicacy of fruit bat cooked in coconut milk, often served whole in the soup - considered a special occasion dish.
Panamanian chicken soup with yam, corn and culantro (sawtooth herb) - considered the country's national comfort food.
Traditional feast where meat and vegetables are wrapped in banana leaves and cooked in an earth oven - PNG's version of the Pacific hangi.
Paraguayan cornbread made with cheese and onions - despite its name ('Paraguayan soup'), it's actually a solid savory cake.
Peru's national dish of raw fish cured in lime juice with onions, chili peppers and cilantro - considered by many the world's best ceviche.
Philippine cooking method (and dish) where meat is marinated in vinegar, soy sauce, garlic and bay leaves, then braised until tender.
Polish 'hunter's stew' of sauerkraut, fresh cabbage and various meats - a dish that improves with each reheating.
Portugal's beloved salted cod, prepared in hundreds of ways (most famously Bacalhau à Brás with shredded cod, eggs and potatoes).
Qatari spiced rice dish with meat (usually lamb or chicken), flavored with loomi (dried lime) and baharat spice blend.
Romanian cabbage rolls stuffed with spiced ground meat and rice, traditionally served at Christmas and other celebrations.
Vibrant beet soup with meat and vegetables, served with sour cream and dill - Ukraine also claims this as their national dish.
Staple stiff porridge made from maize flour, served with beans, vegetables or meat stews - common throughout East Africa.
National stew of goat meat cooked with breadfruit, green papaya and dumplings in a thick, spicy broth.
Saint Lucian breakfast staple of boiled green bananas (called figs) served with sautéed salted cod and spices.
National dish pairing roasted breadfruit with seasoned fried jackfish, reflecting the country's Caribbean culinary traditions.
Samoan dish of taro leaves baked with coconut cream, often wrapped in banana leaves - similar to other Pacific island versions.
San Marino's 'Three Mountains Cake' - layered wafers with chocolate and hazelnut cream, representing the country's three peaks.
National dish of smoked fish cooked with okra, eggplant and palm oil, reflecting the islands' Portuguese and African influences.
Saudi national dish of spiced rice with meat (usually chicken, lamb or camel), flavored with black lime and bay leaves.
Senegal's national dish of fish and rice cooked with vegetables in tomato sauce - considered the country's culinary emblem.
Serbian grilled minced meat sausages made from beef and lamb, served in somun (flatbread) with raw onions and kajmak (creamy dairy spread).
Seychellois version of curry featuring fresh local fish cooked in coconut milk with curry leaves and spices - served with rice.
Sierra Leonean stew of pounded cassava leaves cooked with palm oil, fish or meat, and spices - the country's most popular dish.
Singapore's national dish of poached chicken served with fragrant rice cooked in chicken stock, accompanied by chili sauce and ginger paste.
Slovak national dish of potato dumplings (halušky) mixed with sheep cheese (bryndza) and topped with fried bacon bits.
Slovenian dumplings from Idrija, stuffed with potato, bacon and herbs, traditionally served with bakalca (lamb stew).
Traditional Polynesian staple of fermented taro root paste, similar to Hawaiian poi but with a thicker consistency in the Solomon version.
Somali fermented flatbread similar to Ethiopian injera but thinner, traditionally served with stews for breakfast.
South Africa's national dish of spiced minced meat baked with an egg topping - a legacy of Cape Malay cuisine with Indonesian roots.
South Sudanese fermented sorghum flatbread, served with stews like wal wal (okra stew) or mullah (meat stew).
Valencian rice dish cooked in a wide shallow pan, traditionally with rabbit and snails (paella valenciana) or seafood (paella de mariscos).
Sri Lankan staple meal featuring rice served with multiple curries (meat, fish or vegetable) and accompaniments like sambols and pickles.
Sudanese breakfast staple of mashed fava beans seasoned with garlic, lemon and cumin, often served with bread and eggs.
Surinamese oven dish of pomtajer (taro root) and chicken, reflecting the country's Jewish and Creole culinary influences.
Swedish meatballs made with a mix of beef and pork, served with gravy, lingonberry jam and potatoes - made famous globally by IKEA.
Swiss melted cheese dish served in a communal pot (caquelon) with bread for dipping - originally a way to use aged cheeses in winter.
Syrian national dish of bulgur wheat mixed with ground meat (usually lamb) and spices, served raw, baked or fried in various forms.
Taiwan's national dish featuring tender beef shank in rich broth with noodles, often considered the country's unofficial national dish.
Tajikistan's version of Central Asian rice pilaf, typically made with lamb, carrots and cumin - the country's most celebrated dish.
Staple stiff porridge made from maize flour, served with meat, fish or vegetable stews - the foundation of Tanzanian meals.
Thailand's famous stir-fried rice noodles with eggs, tofu and shrimp, flavored with tamarind, fish sauce and chili - the country's culinary ambassador.
Staple dough made by pounding boiled cassava and plantains, served with soups like light soup (tomato-based) or groundnut soup.
Tongan dish of corned beef and taro leaves baked in coconut milk and onions, wrapped in banana leaves - a legacy of colonial influences.
Trinidadian dish of dasheen leaves cooked with okra, coconut milk and crab - the country's national dish with African roots.
Tunisian version of the North African staple, often served with fish or lamb and flavored with harissa (chili paste).
Turkish grilled meat dishes including döner (rotisserie), şiş (skewered) and Adana (spicy minced meat) - central to Turkish cuisine.
Turkmen version of Central Asian rice pilaf, often featuring carrots, mutton and sometimes dried fruits - the country's most important dish.
Traditional Tuvaluan staple of swamp taro grown in pits, serving as the main carbohydrate source on the coral atolls.
Ugandan staple of steamed green bananas, often mashed and served with meat or bean stews - the country's most important dish.
Ukrainian beet soup with meat and vegetables, served with sour cream and garlic fritters (pampushky) - a point of national pride.
Emirati dish of wheat and meat (usually chicken or lamb) cooked to a porridge-like consistency - traditionally served during Ramadan.
British classic of beer-battered fish (usually cod or haddock) with thick-cut fries, traditionally wrapped in newspaper.
American icon of a ground beef patty in a bun, customizable with endless toppings - representing the country's fast food culture.
Uruguayan sandwich of steak, ham, cheese, egg and toppings - the country's national dish despite its name meaning 'little goat'.
Uzbekistan's national dish of rice cooked with lamb, carrots and spices in a kazan (cauldron) - the centerpiece of any celebration.
Vanuatu's national dish of grated root vegetables (yam, taro or manioc) mixed with coconut milk and meat, wrapped in banana leaves and baked.
While not a country with its own cuisine, Vatican meals typically feature Italian pasta dishes like fettuccine or gnocchi.
Venezuela's national dish of shredded beef, black beans, rice and fried plantains - representing the country's cultural mix.
Vietnam's famous noodle soup with aromatic broth, rice noodles and herbs - the country's culinary ambassador to the world.
Yemeni national dish of meat stew (usually lamb) with hilbeh (fenugreek froth) and sahawiq (chili paste), served in a stone bowl.
Zambian staple of thick maize porridge, served with relishes like vegetables, meat or fish - eaten with the hands.
Zimbabwean version of maize porridge, similar to nshima, served with meat, vegetables or fermented milk - the country's staple food.
